epichains 0.1.0

Getting started with epichains

James Azam

Source: vignettes/epichains.Rmd
epichains.Rmd

Functionality

epichains currently has 4 core functions:

  • simulate_tree(): simulate transmission trees from a given number of chains.
  • simulate_tree_from_pop(): simulate transmission trees from a given number population size and initial immunity.
  • simulate_summary(): simulate a vector of observed transmission chains sizes/lengths from a given number of chains.
  • likelihood(): estimate the likelihood/loglikelihood of observing chains of given sizes/lengths.

Object-orientation

Classes

  • An epichains class:
    • superclass of data.frame with attributes for tracking chain_type as:
      • chains_tree, if returned from simulate_tree() or simulate_tree_from_pop()
      • chains_vec, if returned from simulate_summary().
  • An epichains_aggregate_df class:
    • superclass of data.frame with attributes for tracking if aggregation is done over “time”, “generation” or “both”. Useful for plot method dispatch (see methods section below).

Methods

  • print()
  • summary()
  • aggregate()

Demo

Printing and summary

Code
library(epichains)
# Using `simulate_tree()`
tree_from_pois_offspring <- simulate_tree(nchains = 10,
                                  offspring_dist = "pois",
                                  serials_sampler = function(x) 3,
                                  lambda = 2,
                                  stat_max = 10
                                  )

tree_from_pois_offspring # print the output
#> `epichains` object
#> 
#> < tree head (from first known ancestor) >
#> 
#>    chain_id sim_id ancestor generation time
#> 11        1      2        1          2    3
#> 12        3      2        1          2    3
#> 15        6      2        1          2    3
#> 17        7      2        1          2    3
#> 20        8      2        1          2    3
#> 25        9      2        1          2    3
#> 
#> < tree tail >
#> 
#>    chain_id sim_id ancestor generation time
#> 54        8     13        6          3    6
#> 71        6     13        6          4    9
#> 80        9     13        7          4    9
#> 72        6     14        7          4    9
#> 73        6     15        7          4    9
#> 74        6     16        7          4    9
#> Chains simulated: 10
#> Number of ancestors (known): 7
#> Number of generations: 4
#> Use `as.data.frame(<object_name>)` to view the full output in the console.

# Using simulate_summary()
summary_sim <- simulate_summary(nchains = 50, offspring_dist = "pois",
                                statistic = "length", lambda = 2, 
                                stat_max = 10)

summary_sim # print the output
#> `epichains` object 
#> 
#>  [1] Inf Inf Inf Inf Inf   2 Inf Inf Inf Inf Inf   1 Inf Inf Inf Inf Inf Inf Inf
#> [20] Inf   1   2 Inf Inf Inf Inf Inf Inf   2 Inf Inf Inf Inf   1 Inf   2 Inf Inf
#> [39] Inf Inf Inf Inf Inf Inf Inf Inf Inf Inf Inf Inf
#> 
#>  Simulated chain lengths: 
#> 
#> Max: 2
#> Min: 1

# Using `simulate_tree_from_pop()`

# Simulate with poisson offspring
tree_from_pop_pois <- simulate_tree_from_pop(pop = 1000,
                                                offspring_dist = "pois",
                                                offspring_mean = 0.5,
                                                serial_sampler = function(x) 3
                                                )

tree_from_pop_pois # print the output
#> `epichains` object
#> 
#> < tree head (from first known ancestor) >
#> 
#>   sim_id ancestor generation time
#> 2      2        1          2    3
#> 
#> < tree tail >
#> 
#>   sim_id ancestor generation time
#> 1      1       NA          1    0
#> 2      2        1          2    3
#> Number of ancestors (known): 1
#> Number of generations: 2
#> Use `as.data.frame(<object_name>)` to view the full output in the console.

# Simulate with negative binomial offspring
tree_from_pop_nbinom <- simulate_tree_from_pop(pop = 1000,
                                                  offspring_dist = "nbinom",
                                                  offspring_mean = 0.5,
                                                  offspring_disp = 1.1,
                                                  serial_sampler = function(x) 3
                                                  )

tree_from_pop_nbinom # print the output
#> `epichains` object
#> 
#> < tree head (from first known ancestor) >
#> 
#>   sim_id ancestor generation time
#> 2      2        1          2    3
#> 3      3        2          3    6
#> 
#> < tree tail >
#> 
#>   sim_id ancestor generation time
#> 1      1       NA          1    0
#> 2      2        1          2    3
#> 3      3        2          3    6
#> Number of ancestors (known): 2
#> Number of generations: 3
#> Use `as.data.frame(<object_name>)` to view the full output in the console.

# Likelihoods

chain_sizes <- c(1, 1, 4, 7)
likelihood(chains = chain_sizes, statistic = "size",
                    offspring_dist = "pois", nsim_obs = 100,
                    lambda = 0.5)
#> [1] -8.607196

Aggregation

Code

# aggregate by time
aggregate(tree_from_pop_pois, "time")
#>   time cases
#> 1    0     1
#> 2    3     1

# aggregate by generation
aggregate(tree_from_pop_pois, "generation")
#>   generation cases
#> 1          1     1
#> 2          2     1

# aggregate by both time and generation
aggregate(tree_from_pop_pois, "both")
#> [[1]]
#>   time cases
#> 1    0     1
#> 2    3     1
#> 
#> [[2]]
#>   generation cases
#> 1          1     1
#> 2          2     1
#> 
#> attr(,"class")
#> [1] "epichains_aggregate_df" "list"                  
#> attr(,"chain_type")
#> [1] "chains_tree"
#> attr(,"aggregated_over")
#> [1] "both"
